text:
In terms of coding, you can use them but for the content builder (previewing) we are limited to HubSpot capabilities.
There is a <https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/archives/CCQ7H31D5/p1641560281006100|WIP> from the community (probably as a Chrome extension), that expands such features. Although, unless you agree upon with the client I can't recommend it. For general themes to be sold in the marketplace or multiple clients you are creating a third party dependency of an unofficial component (so it may break in the future with HubSpot updates).

Hi - I'm new here. Hopefully this is a very easy question. Let's assume you have two devs working on a theme. One uses HubSpot's built-in editor, the other uses their own IDE and is running HubSpot CLI. Will these two workflows play nicely? My assumption is yes and that the built-in editor uses the exact same CLI. That said, I don't like to assume anything so please let me know! Thanks in advance :smile:

This does work, as long as your developers are clear about which assets they are editing and when; there is the chance with this situation that one dev (most likely the one using the CLI) can overwrite an asset while the other is active. There is built-in revision history so these changes can be reverted, but using `watch` will lead to A LOT of publish versions. Best practice would be to have both devs use local development and git, just in case.

<@U26BLKGE4> thanks for the reply here. Does the possibility of code collision happen if both are working from the HubSpot built-in editor as well, or is the risk applicable to just this hybrid scenario I described above?
as you mentioned, the risk is also present if both are using the cloud editor

The only exception is editing anything at the page level, generally there will be a warning that another user is currently active. Additionally, the risk is a _bit_ lower because, presumably, a dev using the design manager will not publish as often as a local dev would.
Thanks guys - truly appreciate your time and insight. Enjoy the rest of your week.
